Too much. Much too much butter.
Milk's gone up.
49p a pint.
Eat your egg.
Yes.
Here we are.
No no no no. The grey.
Yes.
...Definitely the grey.
Oh, I haven't had a chance to look at that yet, dear.
Blot it...Blot it..
Wear your scarf. There's a chill out there.
I'm fine, thank you Susie.
Yes. Frightful.
Yes, of course, dear. Today.
What are they playing?
Silly man.
He hasn't got his scarf on.
I'll go.
I've got a place at Oxford.
Mother?
What time is it?
What have you got on your head?
You look ridiculous.
No, Denis, Bosslady no like.
Feet.
I didn't know that you were dropping by today, dear.
Jaqueline...
Of course.
We're having halibut.
Denis!
We must release a statement, offering our condolences.
We must never, ever, ever give in to terrorists.
Oh, below the knee I should think.
No! Don't move those. I haven't finished sorting them.
There was no milk.
I am not for the knackers yet.

If I can't go out to buy a pint of milk then what is the world coming to. Really Carol, please don't fuss about it. You've always been like this, fuss fuss fuss. You must find something better to do with your time. It's most unattractive in a woman. When I was your age the last thing I wanted to do was fuss around my mother.
Obstinate.
Pearls. I'll wear the pearls.
There they are. My little twins.
Jacqueline.
Yes-
Yes I remember-
I've always preferred the company of men-
Well I don't like coalitions, never have...
Oh, yes, to his core. And Mayor of Grantham.
Yes.
Oh, yes. It was a family business.
That and a degree from Oxford.
Whisky.
What I do think is that a man should be encouraged to stand on his own two feet. Yes we help people of course we help people.
Can serve very well for the people of Dartford too.
I know much more than those who have never lived on a limited income. Just like the man or woman on the street, when I am short one week, I have to make economies the next.
A man might call it fiscal responsibility, a woman might call it good housekeeping.
Or woman?
Where?
No, uhm, yes - we have always lived alongside evil. But it has never been so patient, so avid for carnage, so eager to carry innocents with it into oblivion.
Western civilization must root out this evil, wherever it hides, or she risks defeat at the hands of global terror in a nuclear age.
Yes. Clever man. Quite a smoothie.
You don't mind if I sit down...
It used to be about trying to do something. Now its about trying to be someone.
Good night to you.
Can you do the clasp, I can't quite -
Thank you.
What does Mark think about it?
Yes. Tell him to come up. I want to talk to him about it.
Well tell him to come up and see me after he's kissed them good night, would you Carol darling?
You look exhausted, dear. You really must try to get some sleep.
Good night, dear.
Disaster.
Not splendidly enough.
What game?
-And proud of being-
Yes. Yes!
I love you so much but...I will never be one of those women Denis -
No - one's life must matter, Denis. Beyond the cooking and the cleaning and the children, one's life must mean more than that - I cannot die washing up a tea cup.
I mean it Denis, say you understand.
There they are, my little twins.
You look happy.
They grow up so fast.
Mark.
There they are, my little twins.
You look happy.
The right honourable gentleman knows that we have no choice but to shut down the schools!

Because his union paymasters have called a strike deliberately to cripple our economy. Teachers cannot teach when there is no heating, no lighting in their classrooms. And I ask the honourable gentleman, whose fault is that?
If the right honorable gentleman could perhaps attend more closely to WHAT I am saying, rather than HOW I am saying it, he may receive a valuable education in spite of himself!
Yes...
Prime Minister, with the Miners' leader calling today for the army to mutiny in support of the strikes, this seems the wrong time for conciliation.
Right. The only thing you should remember is that everyone else is either reckless or inept. And often both.
One must be brave if one is to take the wheel-
Move over... Move to your right a little bit...
Carol!
To the right. Move to the right!
So sorry! Terribly sorry!
Have you been trying to make breakfast? For Goodness sake, Denis!
I've decided. I'm going to run.
I'm going to run for Leader of the Party.
What's she on about?
Oh, right. Of course.
What I'm saying is that someone must force the point, say the unsayable. None of these men have the guts.
But he's weak, and he's weakened the party. One must know when to go.
You're shaking.
Goodness me! What is the matter with everyone this morning?
And do you need a rest?

We both know that it's highly unlikely that I would ever be elected leader, I'll never be elected leader. But I will run. I will run. Just to nip at their heels and make them reaffirm the principles on which the Conservative Party must stand.
Denis, you married someone who is committed to public service, you knew that. And it is my duty -
Where did you go?
Yes.
When did I lose track of everyone?
Oh that's rather easy to answer, actually. They are unafraid of success.

It's all very well to talk about changing my voice, Mr Reece, but for some of my colleagues to imagine me as their leader would be like imagining, I don't know, being led into battle by their chambermaid. It's my background, and my sex. No matter how I've tried, and I have tried, to fit in, I will never be truly one of them.
Prime Minister?! Oh no. Oh no no no. In Britain? There will be no female Prime Minister here, not in my lifetime. No. And I told Airey, I don't expect to win the leadership, but I am going to run.
Gentlemen, I am in your hands. I may be persuaded to surrender the hat. But the pearls were a gift from my husband on the birth of our twins and they are absolutely non-negotiable.
Maaaaaaaaaaaa.
Denis.
Denis.
Denis.
You are the backbone of our nation! Small firms like Loveday's Ice Cream. How are you? So nice to meet you ladies.
I'll just have a small one, because I'm watching my figure.
That's for you young man!
I passionately believe it's the growth of small businesses into larger ones that is critical for Britain's future.
It has to be something icy on a stick for Denis.
That's the only way we will produce jobs, real jobs, jobs that sustain.

The Trade Union Movement was founded to protect workers. Now it persecutes them. It stops them from working. It is killing jobs and it is bringing this country to its knees. I say enough. It's time to get up. It's time to go to work. It's time to put the Great back into Great Britain!
Oh Airey...
Oh, thanks Airey. Goodnight.
No. No, no! Airey!
Now, as the test draws near, I ask your help. That together we can shake off the shackles of socialism and restore to greatness this country that we love so much.
I should just like to say that I take very seriously the trust the British people placed in me today, and I will work hard every day to live up to that responsibility.
Shoulders back, tummies in!
Oh. Thank you, Michael.
I'm perfectly healthy. There's no need for any of this.
Really it's becoming quite tiresome.
You.
I was on my own for twenty four years before I met you and I can manage perfectly well without you now. So will you please go away and stop bothering me.
No.
Yes, I sleep. Four, five hours a night.
And I stay up late. I always have.
Yes. Of course.
My husband has been gone for years. Cancer.
Yes. It was my idea. To Oxfam.
feeling'?
sorry but we, the group were feeling...' D'you know, one of the great problems of our age is that we are governed by people who care more about feelings than thoughts and ideas.
Now thoughts and ideas. That interests me.
Ask me what I am thinking-

Watch your thoughts, for they become words. Watch your words, for they become actions. Watch your actions, for they become habits. Watch your habits, for they become your character. And watch your character, for it becomes your destiny. What we think, we become. My father always said that.
And I think I am fine.
But I do so appreciate your kind concern.
Oh, do please answer that.
It might be someone who needs you.
Enough. Denis, enough!
When the Himalayan peasant meets the he-bear in his pride -
June.
If I can't hear you then I can't see you. And if I can't see you then you are not here.
And if you are not here, I am not going mad. I will not...I will not go mad.
I don't recognize myself.
They're unveiling that portrait of me at Number 10 next month. The invitation's on the mantelpiece.
I said I didn't want any big fuss but they insisted..
Denis?
Yes, but in order to arrive at the palace on time, Geoffrey and I are will be walking out of that door in 15 minutes. As you can see -
Really.
How much is a pack of Lurpak?
Butter, Francis.
Forty two pence. Anchor butter is forty pence. Flora margarine, still the cheapest, is thirty eight pence. I can assure you I am not out of touch.
What - did you say?
Don't try to hide you opinions.
Ah. Worried about our careers, are we?

Gentlemen, if we don't cut spending we will be bankrupt. Yes the medicine is harsh but the patient requires it in order to live. Shall we withhold the medicine? No! We are not wrong. We did not seek election and win in order to manage the decline of a great nation.
The people of this country chose us because they believe we can restore the health of the British economy and we will do just that!
Anything else?
Thank you. You saved the day once again, Crawfie, you're an angel.
I don't expect everyone just to sit there and agree with me. But what kind of leader am I if I don't try to get my own way - to do what I know to be right.
There must be closures of uneconomic coal mines, we seek only an efficient industry.
violent clashes between protesting miners and police -
There are those who would say hold back, there are those who would make us retreat -
But we shall never give in to them. We shall never waver, not for a second, in our determination to see this country prosper once again.
And now, it must be business as usual.
I know, I'm coming DT. Nearly there -
Denis!
Denis- there you are. Are you alright?
That's when I thought I'd lost you.
Mark?... Hello darling... No, I'm fine... I'm very well...
How is... How's... Sarah?... And the children..?
...Oh... You can't... That's a pity... I was hoping to see you...
Mark?
That was Mark. Not able to come.
Well it costs him a great deal to fly everyone up here.
Yes. He moved to Paris when he was fourteen. He played the King of Siam 4,625 times on the London and Broadway stages. What are you doing?
You're dead, Denis.
Gentlemen, the Argentinian Junta -
Forty-eight hours?
But?
Why were the islands left without any naval protection?
Did we?
I don't think we should be worrying about money at this point, Geoffrey.
The government has now decided that a large task force will sail, as soon as all preparations are complete.
Just like Hawaii, I imagine.

1941, when Japan attacked Pearl Harbour. Did America go cap in hand and ask Tojo for a peaceful negotiation of terms? Did she turn her back on her own citizens there because the islands were thousands of miles from mainland United States? No, no, no! We will stand on principle or we shall not stand at all.
With all due respect sir, I have done battle every single day of my life, and many men have underestimated me before. This lot seem bound to do the same but they will rue the day.
Now, shall I be mother?
Tea, Al, how do you take your tea?
Is this ship a threat?
Sink it.
I must write to them.
The families. I must write to them...
Foreign Secretary...

The peace plan? There will be no appeasement. This is a war. A war they started and by God, we will finish. Shall I tell you what I'm going to write to every single one of these families, these heartbroken families? I am going to tell them that no British soldier will die in vain for the Falklands.
As the only Prime Minister in the history of our country who is also a mother with a son of my own, I can imagine your agony, and your grief.

We were faced with an act of unprovoked aggression and we responded as we have responded in times past: with unity, strength and courage, sure in the knowledge that though much is sacrificed, in the end, right will prevail over wrong.

And I put it to the Honourable Member opposite that this is not a day for him to carp, find fault, demand inquiries- they will happen I can assure him of that for we have nothing to hide- no, this is a day to put difference aside, hold one's head high and take pride in being British.
I don't agree in any measure!
I don't think the country is ready for it yet.
Our policies may be unpopular, but they are the right policies.
There it is again! Why not?

Nonsense. Arrant nonsense. This is a simple proposition. In order to live in this country, you must pay for the privilege- something, anything! If you pay nothing, you care nothing. What do you care where you throw your rubbish? Your council estate is a mess, your town, graffiti, what do you care?

And I see the same thing, the same cowardice in our fight within the European Union, to retain British sovereignty of Britain, the integrity of the pound! Some of you want to make concessions. I hear some of you agree with the latest French proposals.
Right. What can we realistically hope to achieve by the end of session, Lord President?
And why have we not made more progress to date? What is that? Is that the timetable? I haven't seen that. May I see it?
The wording is sloppy here, and here.
I do say so.
This is ridiculous. There are two "T's" in "committee"!
This is shameful. Shameful! I can't even rely on you for a simple timetable! Are you unwell?
If this is the best you can do I had better send you to hospital, and I shall do your job as well as my own and everyone else's.
As the Lord President has come to cabinet unprepared, I am obliged to close this meeting.
Good morning!
Geoffrey-
I am the Prime Minister.
Sweetie?
WESTMINSTER in the moonlight -
Treachery!
It was the people who put me here -
- it's up to them to tell me when to go.
Oh Denis.
154                  I am the Prime Minister.                       154  On her face as CASTA DIVA breaks through.
The Right Honourable gentleman is afraid!
They believe in striking, I believe in working!
Despicable and cowardly -
I offer my resignation after eleven and a half extraordinary years -
-proud to have left Britain in a much better state than when we took office.
What's this then? A radio... How useful.
What?
These inept placators.
Vacillators! Poll takers.
So busy taking the pulse of the public!
These...weak...weak...weak...wea..

Replies.Reply: Don't they know if you take the tough decisions, yes people will hate you today but they'll thank you for generations.
Denis? Denis?
Denis wait...Where are your shoes?

Replies.Reply: Yes...Steady...
Steady...Steady the buffs...
154d                 NO...Not yet...Denis. Wait...I              154d said I don't want you to go yet.
Denis...Please...No...Not...Don't.
Denis!!
Yes, all sorted. Finished.
I was just going to get dressed.
Oh. No, you do it.
No, dear, I'll do it.
No no. I'm not going anywhere.
I like butter.
Good grief! We'll have to economise. I suppose we could always sell the car.
Or take in paying guests!
Watch out. She's on the prowl.
You sure?
Righty ho. Boss knows best.
Don't let her take my paper away.
Atta-girl.
Now look what you've done. Are they to keep the loonies out or you in?
I'll be off then.
They're talking about you again.
Replies.Didascalie: (without taking his eyes of the job)

Replies.Reply: Sun's not quite over the yard arm.
Found it in the cupboard and thought bugger it, it's Friday, why not fancy dress?
Bosslady no like?
It'll be fine. Come on, get your head down, it's ten to three, for God's sake.
Now take it easy, Margaret.
Four down, 9 letters.
Something b something t something n...something something somthing...Refusal to change course-
Eat!
Hang on...Hang on...Hang on...
You shaved thousands off their majority. You did splendidly.
Ah I see. Self pity.
No one is saying you don't need a safe seat. You deserve a safe seat. But it does not come unless you learn to play the game a little.
You are a grocer's daughter-
- in their eyes. A single grocer's daughter. But if you were to become the wife of a moderately successful businessman-
You'd get to parliament, and I'd get to be the happiest man in- in wherever they select you.
Margaret, will you marry me?
Well ?
What ?
We'll get a help for that.
That's why I want to marry you, my dear.
Now eat.
You never really got golf, did you?
Yes, I do, don't I? You're drinking too much.
Whatcha doing?
Not like you. Looking back.
Don't want to dig around too deep, M. Don't know what you might find.
You can rewind it, but you can't change it.
You never really got golf, did you?
Yes, I do, don't I? You're drinking too much.
Whatcha doing?
I can boil a bloody egg.
What for?
Good luck!
It's her driving test this morning!
Are you saying you want to be Prime Minister?
The Prime Minister has been very loyal to you, MT.
I can do it!
I've told you what the matter is.
You're insufferable, Margaret, do you know that?
Don't call it duty. It's ambition which has got you this far.
South Africa.
How many days passed before you realized I was gone? Probably had to ask the cleaning woman where I was.
Too busy climbing the greasy pole MT.
Yes MT!
This is it, steady the buffs old girl.
Just let them look under the bonnet, MT. Check everything is hunky dory.
What is?
What about that medicine man, eh?
Well you really gave it to that quack didn't you, darling ? Just like the old days! Hallucinations my eye!
How dare he?
But then you give us all the run around, don't you?
I know you can hear me, sweetheart, so there's no use pretending you can't.
Dismissed!
She does it in the end. Kills him-
I don't know why you're being so scratchy.
It's not as if you've got anyone else to talk to.

You know, it's a marvel to me that you can still quote huge chunks of Kipling but try remembering the name of that woman who's just made you that godawful cold collation... No? Come on... you can do it... month of the year...

June! Bingo. Knew you'd get there in the end. "When the Himalayan peasant meets the he-bear in his pride, He shouts to scare the monster, who will often turn aside, but the she-bear thus accosted rends the peasant tooth and nail. For the female of the species is more deadly than the male..."
Am I out of the doghouse yet?
Come on love, get to bed. I don't know why you do this to yourself every year, it's a speech at conference, not the Magna Carta!
Time to call it a day, darling.
My shoes!
Boy's always going AWOL.
There you go, making excuses for him. Now look where it's got you.
Did you know Yul Brynner was a gypsy from Vladivostok?
One likes to make an effort. A snifter?
Ah. Well, if I'm dead... who are you talking to? Shall we dance ?
Thatcher, bed.
GOTCHA! Well that paid off old girl! Your ratings soared! From the most hated Prime Minister of all time to the nation's darling...The world was at your feet, and Britain was back in business!
Margaret, you can't let them do this to you. Please, boss.
They'll destroy you.
Throw in the towel now, love.
Steady, MT.
The greatest Prime Minister since Churchill deposed by a bunch of spineless pygmies!
It's all been turned to mush!
By these fools! These lily-livered pinkos!
Very good! These vacillators.
Popularity seekers.
Weak -
Or forget you entirely and chuck you out with the rubbish!
And you did, love, you did.
Steady.
Steady the buffs -
You're going to be fine on your own, love.
You always have been.
Goodness! There you are.
I don't understand how it happened, how could she possibly have got out? It's very very important -
Please just make it really clear.
Beautiful day. Oh, you've made a start. Carol's coming soon, I'll get some bags. Anything you want to go to Mark, I'll bring up a suitcase for it.
Sorry.
Sorry ?
It's taken Carol so long to get her to agree to this. She's been so reluctant to let his things go.
You can never be sure she's taking her medication...I think sometimes she hides them..
She's definitely more distracted than usual today.
I'll give Carol a quick ring, let her know we're back, then I'll put your electric blanket on.
Margaret-
She stands, picking up the cup.
Carol said you might go to the House of Lords today?
Dixon.
Good morning Lady Thatcher. Are you alright ?
How are you feeling ?
I've just been reading about the bombings.
Sorry.
These are the books for you to sign. I brought as many as I could find. Shall we go through your appointments?
We said we'd go through them today.

The invitation has come from Downing Street for the unveiling of your portrait. I'll put it on the mantelpiece, and there's an invitation from Lord Armstrong for lunch on the first Friday of next month.
I think they said Rogers and Hammerstein.
....It looks like a very interesting programme.
Lovely little article in The Telegraph... The Woman Who Changed the Face of History..
Voices from the past intrude -
MARGARET nods to the seamstress, dismissing her-
Did someone cover the butter?
Good girl.
Tomorrow, no matter what they do, it'll be business as usual.
What is the life blood of any community? It's business....
Not just big business but small businesses, like mine.
We on this island are strong.
But we also believe in helping each other. And I don't mean by state hand-outs...
Never run with the crowd, Margaret. Go your own way.
Don't let me down Margaret.
We on this island are strong.
He meant it as an insult but to me it's a compliment. That's why he couldn't beat us, and that's why Hitler can't beat us.

We Conservatives believe in giving people the freedom and opportunity to fulfil their own potential, especially the young. There's no good in pretending we're all equal, we're not all the same, never have been, never will be. We should encourage our children to aspire to achieve more than we have, for our children today will be the leaders of tomorrow.
Leave it.
Margaret!
CUPS!
My hands are still damp.
Margaret!
CUPS!
Two of the small beef, Mr.
Open it then.
MARGARET stirs again, blinking awake.
Oh, rumbled!
Start on the outside...
...and work your way in.
Can I suggest you remove the sticker from the back of your car.
Well then take the sticker off! I call that false advertising! I would say keep the change, but there isn't any change.
Hello June, any news? I've brought every bag I could find.
Mummy-
Right, I'm off June.
Hello Ma. Bloody taxi driver.
Yes, you said yesterday...You wanted to make a start on Dad's things. The cupboards ? Then I can help you dress.
Replies.Didascalie: (Dumping her stuff all over the place)

Replies.Reply: You've got Michael and-
Coming for dinner tonight.
Oh God. Isn't it terrible?
They think it's Al Quaida -
I'm sure they've already-
Now ma, are we going long or just below the knee tonight?
I hear you went out today...You mustn't go out on your own Mummy.
Call Robert he'll get it for you if June's not up-
No one is saying that.
What?
It's nearly all familiar faces, William, Michael and his lovely wife-
And then there's Peter, James R and James T and that very nice man-
- we met last year.
I think he's bringing his new lady friend just to mix it up a bit.
Ma?
The bombings, mummy. Today?
We were just talking about them?
Great to see you, thank you very much for coming.
OK...hold on to me...that's right.
You've got an eyelash.
Make a wish.
I spoke to Doctor Michael today-
He is very good and very expensive-
...I know you're not due to see him for another month but I've spoken to him and he can fit you in tomorrow.
Just for a check up.
Ma please-
Mark?
Mark's with Sarah and the children.
He's not here Mummy.
Mark lives in South Africa...
...you are not Prime Minister anymore and Dad is...Dad is dead-
Righty-ho. Night night Ma. Sleep well.
I swear, it's all gone completely out of my head. My driving instructor thinks I should pass but I feel as if I've hardly had any lessons. Ridiculous isn't it?
Right-o.
But if I move to the right aren't I on the wrong side of the road?
Well he's in the way!
Hey, look at me, driving!
Thanks Ma, that was terrific! I really feel I've got a handle on it now.
You should have seen us, Pa.
Mummy took me for a test drive -
Silly me!
All the time I thought I was having a driving lesson, it was all about my mother, just for a change!
My God, Mum. Are you alright?
Mummy you should have called for help, silly old sausage. Have you not even been in your bed properly? You've done all this?
Yes well don't worry about all this. June and I will crack on with it.
...Shall I call someone, see if anyone can come over and do your hair?
At ten to three this morning an explosion extensively damaged the Grand Hotel in Brighton, scene of the Conservative Party conference.
It's Friday the 4th of May, an historic day for Britain, a Conservative government led by Mrs. Thatcher is set to lead -

The Falkland islands, the British Colony in the South Atlantic, has fallen. Argentina claims its marines went ashore this morning as a spearhead to capture key targets, including the capital, Port Stanley.
The Berlin Wall has fallen. The gates have opened! The police are making no attempt to stop people as they go through.
Mrs Thatcher has failed to win enough votes to secure an outright win in the leadership contest and must now decide whether to put her name forward for the second round.
Ah, Miss Roberts. Hoping to be chosen as our candidate for parliament.
glances up from his drink, taking her in.
They'll be nationalizing the bloody air next.
A very good starting point for the political life, I'm sure.
Nothing like a slice of fiscal responsibility.
...Attlee has his sights set on the steel industry, you mark my words.
So was your father a political man, too, Miss Roberts?
And a grocer as well!
With all due respect, Miss Roberts, what may have served in Grantham-
Miss Roberts, do join the ladies.
Well. That's told us!
Yes, hold your breath, sir, that's government property!
Really?

I'm not sure a home economics lesson is quite what the Dartford constituents need. They see industry being nationalized, the unions on the up, the pound on the slide...whoever can sort that lot out - he's my man.
So, would you -
Oh, thank you. It was lovely, absolutely lovely. And I'm so pleased to see your mother looking so well.
And did you help, err, in the...shop?
Ladies shall we ?
So, Margaret, how would you have dealt with this if you'd been Prime Minister?
The Prime Minister gave a very good statement I thought.
I heard you speak at conference in 1984 in Brighton just after the IRA bombed the Grand Hotel. You were remarkable. I hope you appreciate what an inspiration you have been for women like myself.
Well anyway, I...thank you.

Twenty-four-year-old Miss Margaret Roberts lost her bid to win a seat in Parliament today, but she has put new life into the Dartford Conservative Association. Winning candidate Mr Dodds had better watch out, this bright young woman is on his tail.
Mr Eric Deakins, Labour...
Mrs Thatcher ! Airey Neave.
Important.
If you want to change the party, lead it.
The Right Honourable Lady the Secretary of State for Education.
Order! Order!
Methinks the Right Honourable lady doth screech to much. If she wants us to take her seriously she must learn to calm down!
Why has this Conservative government failed? Why has it forced so many in the public sector into taking strike action to save their own jobs?
Minister, the breakdown of essential public services -
So these power cuts will continue unless we can reach a compromise.
increase in wages. Obviously we can't go anywhere near that. The unions are not our enemies and never have been. We want - and have always wanted - the broadest consensus...
I'm sure we are all in agreement that we must do nothing for the moment that will further inflame the current situation.
- the fact of the matter is, it's absolutely crucial that we are seen by the public to be acting as conciliators and not aggressors.
Yes, Education Secretary.
Be patient. They'll come back on in a minute.
Thank you, Margaret.
Your thoughts are duly noted.
Mrs Thatcher I understand you recently visited the United States of America.
What was it you took away from that visit which may be of value here in Great Britain?
We in Great Britain and in Europe are formed mainly by our history.

Well er...For a start, that hat has got to go. And the pearls. In fact I think all hats may have to go. You look and sound like a privileged Conservative wife and we've already got her vote. You've got lovely hair but we need to do something with it - to make it more-
